notesStmt.note: Edited by Henry Muddiman and Giles Dury. Cf. Nelson and Seccombe.
Imprint varies: No. 1-19 Printed by John Macock; no. 20-53 Printed by John Macock and Tho. Newcomb.
Dates given according to Lady-Day dating.
Reels listed in chronological order of serial publication; holdings dispersed throughout collection.
Reproduction of the originals in the British Library.
Numb. 25 (11-18 Jun. 1660) called: Numb. 26; numb. 29 misprinted as "9".

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: Numb. 27. THE Parliamentary Intelligencer, COMPRISING The Sum of Forraign Intelligence, with the Affairs now in Agitation in England, Scotland, and Ireland. For Information of the People. Publi≈øhed by Order of the late Council of State From Monday June 25. to Monday July 2. 1660.
From Bury in Lanca≈øhire.
div.p:
AMong≈øt all the publique expre≈ø≈øions of Joy every where manife≈øted at his Maje≈øties happy Proclamation, though the Weekly News book made no mention of it, I have not heard the Ceremony was more ≈øolemnly or hand≈øomly managed any where, then by us; which ( ‚Ä¢ o the credit of the Gentleman I cannot but ≈øpeak it) was Mr. Lightfoot our Mini≈øters contrivance; who during the≈øe hazardous times con≈øtantly owned his Maj ‚Ä¢ ≈øties cau≈øe; ‚Ä¢ aid though ma ‚Ä¢ y with the world ‚Ä¢ an round, he ≈øtill per≈øi≈øted to be homo quadratus, and as often as the lea≈øt opportunity ≈øeemed to favor his inclination he publiquely made profe≈ø≈øion of his Loyalty to his Soveraign; wi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øs his bold and frequent mention of his pre≈øent Maj ‚Ä¢ ≈øty „Äà‚óä„Äâ in his publique prayers in Sir George B ‚Ä¢ o ‚Ä¢ h ‚Ä¢
Expedition, for which he ≈øuffered the deprivation of his Benefice.

I had not in≈øi≈øted ≈øo long upon this Gentlemans gallant carriage, had he not been eminently both active and pa≈ø≈øive, as the Scene varied, for the ≈øame Intere≈øt; and were not a large ≈øhare of the loyal expre≈ø≈øions in the en≈øuing Narrative ju≈øtly due to him. In ≈øhort, the ceremony was ≈øo ≈øplendid, ≈øumptuous, and regular, that it will almo≈øt ≈øeem incredible that a place comparatively ≈øo little, ≈øhould equal many more con≈øiderable Towns; and that our Mini≈øter having ≈øatisfied his duty in Divine offices, (and which is more, the expectations of ≈øo numerous ‚Ä¢ n appearance of Gentry) ≈øhould prove ≈øo ingenious a Ma≈øter of Ceremonies: For though many more hands and pur≈øes went to the managing of that affair, yet we were beholding to our Mini≈øters head for much of the contrivance. And as there was cau≈øe of an univer≈øal joy, ≈øo there were large manife≈øtations almo≈øt of a general re≈øentment of it, and effects truly worthy of ≈øo noble a cau≈øe; the Country-Gentlemen, neighboring Clergy, and Soldiers both foot and hor≈øe, each in their ≈øeveral ≈øtations being very cheerful and forward to perform the office of Auxiliaries upon ≈øo good an occa≈øion, and mutual emulation did provoke all of them to outvie each other in expre≈ø≈øions of a hearty obedience to ≈øo grateful commands. After the ceremonies in proclaiming his Maje≈øty were ended, we cau≈øed a Crown which was all that day carried before us, to be placed on the top of a Red cro≈øs erected over the Town- ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ll, where it now remains; and then fea≈øted all the Gentry which came to ≈øee the ≈øolemnity, the Waits with loud mu≈øick u≈øhering in the ≈øolemnity; and we gave the Iri≈øh Brigade which quarter in our town, a ≈øum of monies, and di≈øtributed others to the Ringers, Garland and Bonfire-makers, and al≈øo be≈øtowed the Kings colors on all the hor≈øe and foot, and in fine ≈øuch rude expre≈ø≈øions as Bells, Guns and Bonfires could afford, were abundantly during that day (and the Fires continued fourteen days and nights after) and the next day the joy was ≈øhewn by all the women in the pari≈øh, who ≈øpent it in dancing and other monuments.

div.head: From Stockholm, May 10.
div.p: The 23 In≈øtant, about eleven a clock at night, the corps of the late decea≈øed King, was brought hither, at the light of above 400 Torches, and very magnificent Pompe. There went fir≈øt a great number of Hor≈øemen, after whom marched the ≈øaid Kings Guards; then the Mar≈øhall of the Kingdome, the Count of Levenhaupt, the Deputy of the Nobility, and all the Senators. Then came the Chariot upon which was the Corps covered with a large cloth of black Velvet, whereof the Corners were borne by 4 Gentlemen of the decea≈øed Kings Bed-Chamber, many H ‚Ä¢ lb ‚Ä¢ rd ‚Ä¢ ers being round about it, each of them with a Taper of White Wax, immediatly after marched the young King, with Prince Adolphe his Uncle; and la≈øt of all the Queen Regent his Mother, accompanied by all the Court Ladies; the Corps having been conducted through this Citty, was depo≈øited in the Church of the Ca≈øtle, there to remain until it be tran≈øported to Up≈øal, which is the place where it is to be buried.

div.head: From Vienna, June 5.
div.p:
The 2 In≈øtant, an Expre≈øs arived here from Pre≈øsbu ‚Ä¢ g, who confirmed the bloody battel lately fought between Prince Ragotzy and the Turki≈øh Forces, about Herm≈øt ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t, but with a ≈øucce≈øs much different from what we heard before The ≈øad Prince had five ‚Ä¢ or≈øes killed under him, and lo≈øt mo≈øt of his Infantry and all his B ‚Ä¢ ggag ‚Ä¢ : ≈øo that there is no hope now that he can maintain him≈øelf by force, in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Tran≈øylvania, and much le≈øs that he can recover the good will or the Grand Seignior who hath refu≈øed to accept of the offer he made to him of 500000 Rixdollers yearly, and to j ‚Ä¢ yn his Forces to the Turki≈øh Army, for the execution of the ≈øaid Grand Seigniors de≈øignes again≈øt Hungary; which hath incen≈øed again≈øt him his Imperial Maje≈øty, that it is reported he hath refu≈øed him the inve≈øtiture of ≈øome
Ba ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ wicks he holds in tho≈øe parts. The Leavys are continuing thoroughout the Hereditary Dominions; and as ≈øoon as any number of them are compleated, they are pre≈øently ≈øent away towards the Kingdome of Hungary, to keep the Turks in awe, who doe continue their deva≈øtations, although the Ba≈øhaw of Bu ‚Ä¢ a hath ≈øent again to give a≈ø≈øurance to the Emperor, that the Sultan doth de≈øire to live in good corre≈øpond ‚Ä¢ nce with him; and that very ≈øuddenly an Amba≈ø≈øador would be ≈øent to renue the alliance betwixt the two Empires H ‚Ä¢ s Imperial Maj ‚Ä¢ ≈øties departure for Stiria hath been put off till the 20 In≈øtant, becau≈øe of the indi≈øpo≈øition of the Archduke Leopold, who is to accompany him in that journey. In the mean time his Maje≈øty hath given Audience to the Envoy of the Tartars, who tooke his leave of him, and departed laden with pre≈øents; and the Inve≈øtiure hath beene given to to the Deputies of H ‚Ä¢ l≈øtein for the Lands their Ma≈øter the Duke d ‚Ä¢ th hold of the Empire.

div.head: Konigsbergh June 7. 1660.
div.p: By Letters from Mittaw we have, that the Nobility of Curland hath nominated two of the chiefe≈øt of their body, to go and meet the Duke their Prince, and accompany him hither, where great preparations are a making for his reception, and that the Swedi≈øh forces were begining to remove the Quarters, and leave that Country, marching towards „Äà‚óä„Äâ .

div.head: Plensburg 15 June 1660.
div.p: The Governor of Tonningen having received the news of the conclu≈øion of the Treaty between Swedland and Denmark, on the 13 in≈øtant, cau≈øed thanks to be publickly returned to God for it, and all his Ordnance to be „Äà‚óä„Äâ off. The ≈øame day all the Dani≈øh ≈øhips retired to Gluck≈øtad, by order of the Count Eber≈øtain, who likewi≈øe removed his forces from about this place, which thereby is now free from the blocking up which hath ≈øo long anoyed it.

div.head: Berlin 13 June 1660.
div.p: The Elector of Bramdenburgh hath ordered a publick Thank≈øgiving to be kept throughout all his dominions for the Peace, which now proves to be generall, and for the happy re≈øtoration of the King of England, to whom we heire he hath ≈øent Mon≈øieur Polnitz his Ma≈øter of the Hor≈øe, who, we heare‚ñ™ hath orders to propound unto his Maje≈øty the marriage betwixt the Prince Radzivill with the Prince≈øs of Orange. Our forces are yet in their former Quarters, but ‚Ä¢ s they are like to be hereafter u≈øele≈øs, his Electorall Highne≈øs hath cau≈øed mo≈øt of them to be disbanded.

div.head: Lubeck June 18. 1660.
div.p: The Letters from Copenhagen being not yet arrived, we cannot heare any thing concerning the execution of the la≈øt Treaty, but only we are informed that the Swedes were begining to tran≈øport the Booty they had in Zealand, and that their German forces had received orders to retire into the places of the Archbi≈øhoprick of Bremen, Pomerania and Mecklburgh, and that the re≈øt was to be tran≈øported into Swedland. And that in con≈øequence of the ≈øub≈øcription of the peace, the Swedi≈øh Admiral, who was abord Vice-Admiral Ruyters Ship, had leave to go and ki≈øs the hands of the King and Queen of Denmark at Copenhagen, where great rejo ‚Ä¢ cings were made, but greater were yet preparing, for the ≈øaid Peace.

div.head: From Edinburg June 19. 166 ‚Ä¢ .
div.p:
Out of the affection I have for you, I have with every conveniency ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ q ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
ted you with what pa≈ø≈øeth here worthie of your Knowledge or ob≈øervation and at this time e≈øpecially, I have made hold to borrow a few minutes from the publick ≈øolemnities to give you that in brief which we are celebrating wi ‚Ä¢ h that ≈øplendor and affection and unfained token ‚Ä¢ of joy, that the like hath not been ≈øeen before in this Nation; for great and wonderfull is the Lords work of deliverance in that day, when we expected to be overturned with c ‚Ä¢ nfu≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ and covered with de≈øolation.

The Magi≈øtra ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ of this City and our Pre ‚Ä¢ by ‚Ä¢ ry, bring mo≈øt ≈øen≈øible of „Äà‚óä„Äâ great mercy received, did appoint this the day of their publick thanksgiving to God for his ≈øignal love and kindne≈øs ≈øhowed to them in inve≈øting our mo≈øt gracious Soveraigne w ‚Ä¢ th his T ‚Ä¢ roane of England and Ireland, and for re≈øtoring him to his Goverment ove ‚Ä¢ this h ‚Ä¢ s ancient N ‚Ä¢ tion, that for twenty hundred ye ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , unle ‚Ä¢ the Scep ‚Ä¢ er of his Royall ance≈øto ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ and
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
have given notice of this their re≈øolution to all the Burghs and Presbyter ‚Ä¢ es of Scotland, de≈øiring their concurrence That ‚Ä¢ s the cau≈øe is ≈øo their joy may be univer≈øall; Our Mini≈øters „Äà‚óä„Äâ then Sermons with ≈øo much fervency and pa≈ø≈øionat expre≈ø≈øions delivered what great kindenes the Lord had f ‚Ä¢ r ‚Ä¢ n ‚Ä¢ , in re≈øtoring to us our good King, that it hath n ‚Ä¢ t been ob≈øerved that at any time their exhortations have been entertained w ‚Ä¢ th ≈øuch attention, and ≈øo plentifull tears by their Auditory. The Engli≈øh Officers of State and War, ob≈øerved the Thank giving with no le≈øs joy and devotion after Sermon, and af ‚Ä¢ er we had all dined tog ‚Ä¢ ther, we all marched from the Councell ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ -hou≈øe to the Cro≈øs, in this ‚Ä¢ o ‚Ä¢ , the Town Councel in their Gowns, with th ‚Ä¢ ir Trumpets ≈ø ‚Ä¢ u ‚Ä¢
ing before them, went fir≈øt; then two B ‚Ä¢ lles before the Engli≈øh Commi≈ø≈øioned and Officers, and two behind them went next: The Provo≈øt all alone before the Scotch Nobility and Gentry that are in Town, and two ‚Ä¢ ui ‚Ä¢ ies with the Dean o ‚Ä¢ God and The ‚Ä¢ aurer followed after; their Guards neer ≈øix hundred Cit ‚Ä¢ zens in com ‚Ä¢ ly apparel, armed with Swords and Parti≈øans, the Cro≈øs was covered with artificial Vi ‚Ä¢ s loaden with Grapes, both good ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ are ‚Ä¢ w ‚Ä¢ ne‚ñ™ plenti ‚Ä¢ uly ≈øpringing out from all its Channels, on its Heads a Bacchus be≈øt ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ di ‚Ä¢ ng a Hor≈øh ‚Ä¢ ad, with two or three Satyres, d ‚Ä¢ d with then ‚Ä¢ mick ge≈øtures and je≈øts, en ‚Ä¢ ertain the beholders, ‚Ä¢ little below the Cr ‚Ä¢ within a Ra ‚Ä¢ , was erected a ‚Ä¢ cuff ‚Ä¢ ld ≈øix foot high, on which was pl ‚Ä¢ d a large Table covered with a rich Banquet, ≈øerved up in gl ‚Ä¢ ≈øs, and repre≈øenting divers forms and devices: As His ‚Ä¢ aje≈øties Arms, the Arms o ‚Ä¢ the City, and divers Exotick ‚Ä¢ r ‚Ä¢ es were rai≈øed, loaden with their Leaves and Fruits, &c. the Table being ≈øurrounded with above one hundred per≈øons of eminency. The Mu≈øick and breaking of Gla≈ø≈øes were ≈øeconded by three g ‚Ä¢ neral Vollies of the Hor≈øe and Foot, who recei ‚Ä¢ ed an hand≈øom an≈øwer from the great Guns of the Ca≈øtle, Citadel and Sh ‚Ä¢ ps in the Road, and all were ‚Ä¢ o ‚Ä¢ oed by ‚Ä¢ oyful Acclamations of the people.

After this the forces drew off, affording the civilities of view to the p ‚Ä¢ ople, among≈øt whom the di≈øhes and banquet were hurled, and ≈øo aro≈øe and marched down to the Pi ‚Ä¢ zzo of the Palace of Holy: o ‚Ä¢ hou≈øe, fir≈øt the Comm ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ioners next the Mayor General with his Army, and af ‚Ä¢ them th ‚Ä¢ City ‚Ä¢ agi≈øtrates with their guards; whence after the muskets had ‚Ä¢ luted the ‚Ä¢ there w ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ h h ‚Ä¢
vers vollies and had receaved a returne from the great guns of the Ca≈øtle, citadel and ≈øea as f ‚Ä¢ rmerly they marched back againe quite thorough the City „Äà‚óä„Äâ to the Ca≈øtle-hill from whence eve ‚Ä¢ rie o ‚Ä¢ e apart returne „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øpend the re≈øt of the evening with their friends in m ‚Ä¢ rth and m ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ uall Joy and entertainements. But now begin the Bells and the Fireworks, therefore I mu≈øt be gone to a≈ø≈øi≈øt in the dances of our Magi≈øtrates and citizens about the bonfires, and on my knees to remember the health of my Soveraign, and his royal „Äà‚óä„Äâ , and the pro≈øperity of his Excelleny and all tho≈øe Heroes and Nobles who have been in≈øtrumental, or do rejoice wish us in this our great deliverance and happine≈øs.

div.head: Whitehall.
div.p: His Sacred Maje≈øty, our of a ≈øen≈øe of the high deferes of Col. John Covert of Slaugham in the county of Su≈ø≈øex, (who formerly ≈øerved in the Army of his late Maje≈øty of ever ble≈ø≈øed memory with much courage and fidelity, and ‚Ä¢ ath ≈øince that, notwith≈øtanding the cruelty of his enemies, and their per ‚Ä¢ ecuring of him for continuing his allegiance to his pre≈øent Maje≈øty, ≈øtill remained un≈øhaken i ‚Ä¢ his re≈øolutions to perform his duty, for which he was by Oliver Cromwell impri≈øoned in the Tower) was graciou≈øly plea≈øed fir≈øt to Knight him, and then give him a Patent for Barone ‚Ä¢ .
His Maje≈øty conferred the honor of Knighthood on VVilliam Poultney, a per≈øon that ever had a great civility for all that were for the Royal cau≈øe, and a loyal heart for his Maje≈øties ≈øervice.
Col. Roger Mo≈øtyn is made Gentleman of the privy ‚Ä¢ chamber to his Maje≈øty to enjoy all priviledges, &c.
On Monday, the right honorable the Earl of Shrewsbury pre≈øented to his Maje≈øty an Addre≈øs of the Nobility and Gentry of the County of VVorce≈øter, entituled,

p.hi: To the Kings mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty, The Humble Adddre≈øs of the Nobility and Gentry in the County of Worce≈øter.

div.p:
The Addre≈øs was ≈øub≈øcribed, Tho. VVind≈øor, Tho. Coventry, VVill Ru≈ø≈øell, and above fifty „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚ñ™ His Maje≈øty returned them his hearty thanks telling them he was well a≈ø≈øured of their loyalty and affection, and ≈øhould ever have a good e≈øteem of them.
One Payne, formerly a Me≈ø≈øenger of Oliver Cromwell, is ≈øecured; there beng information again≈øt him, that he was the Executioner of that execrable murder of his late Maje≈øty.
On Monday, Serjeant Atkins, a per≈øon of known integrity and great learning in the Law, ≈øate Baron of the Exchequer.

It being prohibited by the Hou≈øe of Commons, upon the mi≈øcarriage and abu≈øes of ≈øome idle Pamphleters‚ñ™ that any of the Votes of that Hou≈øe ≈øhould be printed without ≈øpecial Order, the Reader is de≈øired to excu≈øe us, if in obedience to them we cannot yet give him ≈øo full ≈øatisfaction.

Books from the Office of Intelligence having formerly given you an account that Mr Scot one of the late pretended High Court of Ju≈øtice for trial of his late Maje≈øty was brought to We≈øtmin≈øter; I mu≈øt confe≈øs, though enquired of by many, I could not give ≈øatisfaction therein, being tender to gain≈øay any thing I did not well know e≈øpecially in a matter concerning Mr. Scot, with who in the Pamphleret formerly kept ≈øuch con≈øt ‚Ä¢ nt intelligence, till meeting with a meer notation of his, I was informed that he was at Bru≈ø≈øels, where he had rendred him≈øelf ‚Ä¢ o Sir Henry de V ‚Ä¢
‚ñ™ till his Maje≈øties plea≈øure ≈øhould be further known concerning him, laying him≈øelf now at la≈øt at the feet of his Maje≈øties mercy as his onely ≈øecurity.

div.head: Naples May 29.
div.p:
Ten ≈øhips, whereof ≈øix do belong to the Princ ‚Ä¢ of Monte≈øarchio his Squadron, we ‚Ä¢ r from hence this we ‚Ä¢ , with the 2000 Napolitan ‚Ä¢ oot, that were in our Ar≈øenal, commanded by Don Emanuel Caraffa, their Ma≈øter of campe, and a German Regiment of about 1000 Soldiers, who are all to
be tran≈øported into Spain. They do al≈øo carry thither a great quantity of Provi≈øions and Ammunitions for the War again≈øt Portugal.

div.head: Madrid June 2.
div.p: We hear by Letters from Cadiz, that our Fleet was gone from thence the Fourteenth of the la≈øt month; con≈øi≈øting is two Men of War, laden with ≈øilver, and twenty four laden with Merchandizes. We have heard likewi≈øe, that the Portugais, to the number of 500 hor≈øe and 2000 foot, with two ≈ømall Field pieces, had under „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øomthing upon Ale ‚Ä¢ gais, but that they were ≈øtoutly repul≈øed by the Garri≈øon, and the Inhabitants of that place‚ñ™ and the Governor of „Äà‚óä„Äâ Rodrigo being gone „Äà‚óä„Äâ their relief with the „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , had ≈øo hot ‚Ä¢ g charged the Enemies as they were retiring, that he killed 200 of them, and took 100 Pri≈øoners. The States of both the Ca≈øtilles have been ≈øummoned again≈øt the 15. in≈øtant.

div.head: Rome June ‚Ä¢ .
div.p: This week Prince Ludovi≈øio went from hence to take ≈øhipping at Civitta Vecchia, upon the Captain Galley of the Duke of „Äà‚óä„Äâ , which is to carry into Arragon.

div.head: Genoa June 12.
div.p: The Seventh in≈øtant, the Sieurs France≈øco Maria Lomellino, Gio Buti≈øta Giovo, and Giaccomo Maria Garbarino were elected Senators, and the Sieurs Pietro Maria Gentile, and France≈øco Maria Spinola Procurators, for the Supream Government of this Common wealth for two years.

div.head: Turin June 19.
div.p: The 17 in≈øtant, this Court went from hence for Frone, where they are to remain, during the great heat of Summer. The two Foot Regiments whom his Royal Highne≈øs hath given to the Venetians, are likewi≈øe gone from Trin, to go down upon the Po to Venice.

The Governor of Milan hath demanded leave to ra ‚Ä¢ ≈ø ‚Ä¢ here a Regiment of Hor≈øe of 500 men to ≈øerve again≈øt Portugal, under ≈øuch Officers as his ≈øaid Highne≈øs will be plea≈øed hi ‚Ä¢
≈øelf to appoint.

div.head: St. John de Luz, June 21. 1660.
div.p:
Two dayes afore the departure of the Court from hence, the Count of Fuen≈øaldagne arrived here with a fine equipage, having eight Coaches, each with ≈øix hor≈øes, three Litters, twenty four Mules with Coverts of Crim≈øon Velvet, imbroidered with gold and ≈øilver, two hundred hor≈øes all gallantly furni≈øhed, thirty pages, and many footmen, all in rich cloaths, laced with gold and ≈øilver lace. The Duke of Crequi was ≈øent to complement him from the King and Queen, and afterwards was carried to his audience, where the Duke of E≈øpe ‚Ä¢ non put on his hat as ≈øoon as that Amba≈ø≈øador covered him≈øelf, which cau≈øed the Dukes of So ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øons and Armagnac to ab≈øent them≈øelves from that ceremony. The King expre≈ø≈øed to the ≈øaid Amba≈ø≈øador his great ≈øatisfaction of the Queen, and that he was much beholding to the King his Brother, his Unckle, and his Father-in-law, for be≈øtowing on him that Prince≈øs. From thence the Amba≈ø≈øador went to the Queen-Mother, where at fir≈øt having covered him≈øelf, he ‚Ä¢ ood ba ‚Ä¢ e during all the re≈øt of the time of his audience, afterwards he went to ≈øee the Queen. The King entertained him at night with a Spani≈øh Comedy, where he had a place under the Canopy, three places lower then Mon≈øieur the Kings Brother: All the time of the Comedy the King did nothing but whi≈øper to the Queen. I hath been ob≈øerved by the whole Court, that the King and Queen are extremely fond one of the other, and can hardly part. It is reported, that the fir≈øt thing the Queen asked of the King, hath been, that ≈øhe might alwayes go with him where≈øoever he ≈øhould go either to any journey, or to hunt, a≈ø≈øuring his Maje≈øty that ≈øhe may very well follow him on hor≈øeback. She hath ≈øent back again all the Spani≈øh Ladies that came along with her into France, except only two Maids of Honor, Chamber maid, a Dwarf,
and two other Servants. The King having asked of her Maje≈øty whom of the ≈øervants ≈øhe would keep; ≈øhe an≈øwered, ≈øhe would keep none except his Maje≈øty would give her leave.

div.head:
St. Seba≈øtian,
June 21. 1660.
div.p: Don Lewis d' Aro is to go from hence this day for Madrid. We hear that his Catholick Maje≈øty intends to ≈øend the Marque≈øs of Con≈øtans to congratulate the King of England for his happy re≈øtauration, and that he hath de≈øigned the Baron of Battevil to be Amba≈ø≈øador Extraordinary to the ≈øaid King. We hear from Flanders that all the Spani≈øh Forces that were in the Garri≈øons and places, and ≈øuch as were under the pay of the Flemi≈øh, amounting to fifteen or ≈øixteen Regiments, both hor≈øe and foot, were commanded to draw about Mardike; it is not known whether it be upon an intention to disband them, or for ≈øome other de≈øign.

The 16 in≈øtant, the Chiaux of Tunis lately returned hither from the Court, went away with his Maje≈øties Deputy, who is ≈øent about the liberty of the French Slaves. The twenty, the Switzers remaining here, were drawn out to quarter beyond the Port, by the order of the Duke of Mercoeur, who went ye≈øterday for Aix. A Bark lately come from Barbary doth relate, that twenty Men of War from Algier, having met with a Merchant Ship of ours going towards the Levant, have taken her, and made ≈ølaves all the men that were aboard of her.

div.head: Cah ‚Ä¢ rs the ≈øame date.
div.p:
M. Sevin our Bi≈øhop, ≈øince his return from Toulou≈øe,
where he was gone to be ≈øworn to his Maje≈øty, hath wholly applyed him≈øelf to the holding of a Synod here. The 17 in≈øtant, he cau≈øed the funeral ceremonies to be performed in his Cathedral for his Predece≈ø≈øor. There were pre≈øent to the ceremony all the Corporations of this City, and mo≈øt part of the Nobility and Gentry of Q ‚Ä¢ ercy, with above eight hundred Churchmen, Secular and Regular. The Bi≈øhop of Montauban made the Funeral Sermon with great applau≈øe.

The 21 in≈øtant, the Duke of E≈øpernon, Governour of this Province, being arrived here to give the nece≈ø≈øary orders for the reception of the Court, was received upon the Port, with the noy≈øe of our Artillery, by our Jurates, in who≈øe name the Count d' E≈øtrades our Major, made a ≈øpeech to him. He was after complemented in his own hou≈øe by the Deputies of the Parliament, and of the Court of Aydes, and by the Trea≈øurers of France, the Senechal, and the other Corporations of this City, who hath expre≈ø≈øed much joy for his return. The 23, their Maje≈øties having received the fir≈øt re≈øpects of our Jurates, by their Deputies at Bazas, and of the Parliament, by theirs at Langon, arrived here ye≈øterday upon a very gallant boat they had taken about Cadillac. At their lighting, the Duke of E≈øpernon, followed by abundance of Nobility, pre≈øented them the Jurates, and after their ≈øpeeches, the Keys unto t ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Queen, by order of the King. Their Maje≈øties were conducted afterwards through the ≈øtreets richly hung, and at the noy≈øe of the Canons to their lodgings, where all the Corporation, pre≈øented al≈øo by the Duke of E≈øpernon, waited upon their Maje≈øties this day, and made them their ≈øubmi≈ø≈øions. The 21, about four a clock in the morning, we were much affrighted here by an Earthquake, which cau≈øed ≈øome ≈øtones to fall
down from one of our Steeples. We have heard that the ≈øune hath happened about the ≈øame time in ≈øeveral places hereabouts.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENTS.
div.p: THe Reader is de≈øired to take notice, that ≈øome unworthy per≈øon ha ‚Ä¢ h ≈øo mangled that Excellent Poem that was lately ≈øet forth (called Iter Boreale) by a Rural pen (as the ingenious Author was plea≈øed to „Äà‚óä„Äâ him≈øelf) you may know it by the Effigy of the Lord General Monck affixed with it in the ≈øame leaf, tending to the wrong of the Author, and the abu≈øe of the buyer, by taking here a line or two, and there a line or two, and forward and backward in a confu≈øed manner, ≈øo that the ≈øen≈øe of the Author is (as much as in him lies) totally perverted.

div.head: Adverti≈øements of Books.
div.p: The Extravagant Shepherd; or the Hi≈øtory of the Shepherd Ly≈øis, an Anti-Romance, in fourteen books; written originally in French, now made Engli≈øh, and publi≈øhed the ≈øecond time. To be ≈øold by Thom ‚Ä¢ s Ba≈ø≈øet in St. Dan≈øtans Churchyard in Fleet≈øtreet.

Cele≈øtial Amitles, or a Soul ≈øighing for the love of her Saviour, by Edward Rey
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ll.
The benefit of affliction, by the ≈øame Author.

An Advice again≈øt Libertini≈øm, ≈øhewing the great danger thereof, and exhorting all to zeal for the truth, by the ≈øame Author. All three ≈øold by Abel Roper at the Sun again≈øt St. Dun≈øtans Church in Fleet≈øtreet.

Confirmation and Re≈øtau ‚Ä¢ ation the nece≈ø≈øary means of Reformation and Reconciliation, for the healing of the corruptions and divi≈øions of the Churches, ≈øubmi≈ø≈øively but earne≈øtly ‚Ä¢ endered to the con≈øideration of the Soveraign Powers, Magi≈øtrates, Mini≈øters, and People &c. By Richard Baxter, an unworthy Mini≈øter of Chri≈øt, that longeth to ≈øee the healing of the Churches. Sold by Jo≈øeph Cranford at the Ca≈øtle and Lyon in St. Pauls Church-yard.

‚òû There is now Publi≈øhed that long expected and much admired Piece, Intituled, The World Surveyed: or, The Famous Voyages and Travels of Vincent le Blanc, or, White of Mar≈øcilles; who from the age of 14 years, to 78. travelled through mo≈øt parts of the World; Containing a more exact de≈øcription thereof, then hath hitherto been done by any other Author. The whole Work enriched with many authentick Hi≈øtories. Originally written in French, and falt ‚Ä¢
fully rendered into Engli≈øh. By F. B. Gent

Aminta, The famous Pa≈øtoral. Written in Italian by the Exqui≈øite P ‚Ä¢ n of the admired Poet Signor' Torquato Ta≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ s; and Tran≈ølated into Engli≈øh Ver≈øe, by Iohn Dancer, with divers other Poems. Both Printed for Iohn Starkey at the Miter in Fleet-≈øtreet, betwixt the Middle Temple Gate, and Temple Barre.
The Character of Italy, or the Ireland Anatemized by an Engli≈øh Chyr ‚Ä¢ ugion‚ñ™
The Character of Spain, or an Epitemie of their Vertues and Vices. Both ≈øold by Nathaniel Brook at the Angel in Cornhil.

All Tenants for Lives, or for Years, which ‚Ä¢ old of the Bi≈øhops, or D ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ns, and Chapters, are de≈øired to meet on Tue≈ødaies and Saturdaies, at eight of the clock in the morning, at the Sign of the Legg at We≈øtmin≈øter, in the Palace-yard, to con≈øider of their re≈øpective intere≈øts.

A ≈ømooth black dog, le≈øs then a Greyhound, with white under his bre≈øt, belonging to the Kings Maje≈øty, was taken from Whitehall the eighteenth day of this in≈øtant June, or thereabout. If any one can give notice to John Ellis, one of his Maje≈øties Servants, or to his Maje≈øties back-≈øtairs, ≈øhall be will rewarded for their labour.

Whereas Tho. Rawlins, chief Graver of his Maje≈øties Mint and Seals, by rea≈øon of his ≈øufferings occa≈øioned by graving of a Seal for his late Maje≈øty of ever ble≈ø≈øed memory, has not kept any certain lodgings; the≈øe are therefore to let all know that are in any office, that have ≈øeals from his Maje≈øty, that they mu≈øt p ‚Ä¢ ≈øs by Warrant to him, and that at pre≈øent he lives in Long Acre, next door to the Pe≈øtle and Morter, but ≈øhall ≈øpeedily remove to the Mint within the Tower of London. Tho. Rawlins, chief Graver to his Maje≈øty.

The 21 in≈øtant, the Royal Prince≈øs having been entertained with rich Pre≈øents by the Chamber of the Ea≈øt India Company, went away from hence towards Harlem. The affairs of the Prince her Son go on very well in our Provinces, the States of Zealand having appointed Commi≈ø≈øioners to draw a Li≈øt of the charges and places formerly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by his Predece≈ø≈øors, and ≈øettle all things again as they were in 1651.

By Letters from Edinborough of the 21, we have this further accompt of the ≈øolemnity, That the Major General, after his remembrance of his Maje≈øty to the Earl of Seaford, fired the great Cannon called Monnce Megg (a Cannon never fired but on extraordinary occa≈øions) after which followed all the Guns in Edinborough Ca≈øtle, Leith Cittadel, and the ≈øhips in the Road. A plentiful Large≈øs was be≈øtowed among≈øt the Souldiery to heighten them in their joyes; about fifteen hundred bonfires were made on Arthurs Seat, one of forty load of coals, and at the Major Generals door one almo≈øt as big. After this
was variety of fire-works, ≈øome burned in the water, other flew in the ayr, two Ca≈øtles firing one again≈øt the other, then ≈øeveral ≈øorts of boxes thrown into the ayr, and falling in ≈øeveral ≈øhapes, which with divers others, gave great content to the ≈øpectators.

My Corre≈øpondent there did further inform me, that what he vvrit concerning Major Abernthey, vvas too greedily taken up bp him from a brisk report that vvas rai≈øed by ≈øome ill people, and de≈øires it may be amended in the next Print, vvhich for his and the Readers ≈øatisfaction I have done accordingly. As for Major Aberin, my friend of the Intelligence Office, hath not yet told me vvhere he lives, till which time I mu≈øt de≈øire that Gentlemans pardon.

As for what concerns Captain Rolle, I confe≈øs I had ≈øuch a paper left at my hou≈øe, and ≈øo ≈øub≈øcrib ‚Ä¢ d, as he puts in his Pamphlet, but whether Mr. Calmady's hand or no I know not; I ≈øhall ≈øuddenly endeavour to wait upon him, and on Thur≈øday next in Publicus will give a faithful accompt of it.

For the re≈øt of his pittiful foolery, to tho≈øe that know me, I need make no Apology, to tho≈øe that do not, it will be enough to tell them, that I never „Äà‚óä„Äâ any thing of this ≈øort till entreated to it, for a ju≈øt vindication of his Excellency, and his Army, to give faithful intelligence of their tran≈øactions, which were at that time ≈øo ba≈øely and fal≈øly repre≈øented here by the Pamphleteers then in being. His Excellency was plea≈øed then to ≈øend me ≈øeveral of his papers to commit to the Pre≈øs, which when known to the world, any ≈øober di≈øcreet man may judge with what cautiou≈øne≈øs and de≈øign I mu≈øt behave my ≈øelf, with what reluctancy to my ≈øelf I was forc'd ≈øometimes to imitate this very fellow (I m ‚Ä¢ an no further, though then in writing) to free my ≈øelf from the inqui≈øi ‚Ä¢ ion of his prying Ma≈øter, who employed ≈øuch bu≈øie in≈øtruments to intrap men; how could I then ≈øafely repre≈øent the m ‚Ä¢ mb ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s that de≈øir'd a Free Parliament, if not in a di≈øguize, which however was nece≈ø≈øary ≈øhould be done to balance tho≈øe things he ≈øo often foi≈øted in, and crowded week after week into his books, ≈øuch as his Dare-bones Petition, and that pretended to be the Waterm ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s, which ≈øu≈øpition might not a naked ≈øimplicity have ca≈øt upon the Ma≈øter I wrote for? This though his ≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d ‚Ä¢ owne≈øs cannot reach, wi≈øe men have though meritorious, and in con≈øideration of my ≈øervice, the late Council of State ordered me one day i ‚Ä¢ the week „Äà‚óä„Äâ be the intelligence, and none el≈øe on the ≈øame day, which I mu≈øt tell my G ‚Ä¢ ntleman I think of as ≈øufficient power, as to the writing of „Äà‚óä„Äâ I confe≈øs I have never yet ≈øeen his power, but becau≈øe the Gentleman in ≈øome of his former papers hath „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ I knew it, I'le tell him my opinion of it, that he may have paper to keep a „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ to give information of mone ‚Ä¢ to be laid ou ‚Ä¢ in B ‚Ä¢ ina ‚Ä¢ ia, or where a „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ with ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øt ≈øecurity venture ‚Ä¢ o have his corns „Äà‚óä„Äâ , w ‚Ä¢ the R ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ earcher liv ‚Ä¢ s, „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ is to be let on the B ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e-≈øide, where young m ‚Ä¢ n and old M ‚Ä¢ rrons „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , and that bargains are made to be the ‚Ä¢ e‚ñ™ bu ‚Ä¢ how this entitles „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ; I leave it to him≈øelf to di≈øcount. „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ is by Neth ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ mizing
„Äà‚óä„Äâ , they are hi ‚Ä¢ Tides that honor him; he „Äà‚óä„Äâ made like „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ of
Offal, had he not crept into his Livery, he might have gone thred-bare „Äà‚óä„Äâ this time, and yee I do not ≈øay he Nedhamizes, cloath him in purple, and he will pa≈øs but ≈øo the ≈øame creature ≈øtill. The Maxime in this is true, Corruptio u ‚Ä¢ ius e≈øt generati ‚Ä¢ alterius, Sir Politick would be, might have been diviller to his Godfather, for ≈øurely he gave him his name; but no wonder if he be ir≈øeverent to him, that ≈øhew'd ≈øo much ingratitude to his late Patron. I will not trouble my ≈øelf any more with his impe ‚Ä¢ tinencies, as to what he can ≈øay of me in relation to my writing, I think him ≈øoberly an≈øwered, for his follies ≈ølightly.

div.head: Whitehall.
div.p: On Thur≈øday, being the day appointed for the Thank≈øgiving for his ≈øacred Maje≈øties re≈øtauration, in his Maje≈øties pa≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ ge between the Guard-chamber, and his Clo≈øet, ≈øtood a per≈øon neer up to the wall with a drawn ≈øword under his cloak, which was not for ≈øome time di≈øcovered; but his Maje≈øty pa≈ø≈øing to t ‚Ä¢ e Clo≈øet, George Charnock, Serjeant at Arms, ca≈øting his eye about for the ≈øecurity of his Maje≈øties per≈øon, di≈øcovered the glittering of the Sword, and thereupon pre≈øently with his Mace ≈øeized on the per≈øon, took from him th ‚Ä¢ ≈øaid naked ≈øword, and upon view found the ≈øame to be a ≈øhort ≈øword, back ‚Ä¢ ilted, hacked half way down from the point, a weapon fit for a dangerous de≈øign, but by the care and prudence of that Gentleman, his Maje≈øties faithful ≈øervant, all intended mi≈øchief was prevented, the per≈øon ≈øecured, and his Maje≈øty informed thereof by the Right Honorable and truly Noble Lord, the Earl of Pembroke, and the party remains under examination.

Friday. His Maje≈øty with his two Royal Brothers, the Dukes of York and Gloce≈øter, with ≈øeveral of the Nobility and Gentry, went to Copt-hall, where they were highly treated by the Earl of Middle≈øex.
On Saturday his Maje≈øty, with their Royal Highne≈ø≈øes his Brothers, his Excellency, with divers of the Nobility and Gentry, were highly entertained at P ‚Ä¢ ehampton.

div.head: From his Excellencies Quarters at the Cock-pit.
div.p: On Munday his Excellency granted a Commi≈ø≈øi ‚Ä¢ n to Major Richard Fincher, to be Major to Col. Nortons Regiment at Port≈ømouth. Al≈øo a Commi≈ø≈øion to Captain Potts, ≈øon to Sir John Potts, to be a Captain in the ≈øame Regiment.
Sir John Mennes having a Patent from his Maje≈øty to be Governour of Deal Ca≈øtle, his Excellency ordered the pre≈øent Governour forthwi≈øh to ≈øurrender it to him.
William Bing E≈øq hauing a Patent for Weymouth Ca≈øtle, his Excellency ordered the p ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øent Governour forthwith to ≈øurrender it to him.

His Excellency hath by Commi≈ø≈øion given the Command of the Regiment which was lately Col. Hackers, to Francis Lord Hawley, Vi≈øcount Duncann ‚Ä¢ n. He hath ‚Ä¢ ikewi≈øe given a Commi≈ø≈øion to Sir Chiche≈øter Wrey, to be Major of that Regiment, to Sir Francis Vincent Baronet, Sir Thomas Sinkeley, James Muddifor ‚Ä¢ , and „Äà‚óä„Äâ
She ‚Ä¢ rard, to be Captains in the ≈øame Regiment.
On Friday his Excellency ≈øate in the Hou≈øe of Commons, and „Äà‚óä„Äâ his leave of them, having ≈øuch Honours conferred on him by his Maje≈øty, as puts him in an high ‚Ä¢ capacity.

Major Abr. Holmes, Timothy Clare, Nicholas Lockyer, R Jones, Anth Spinage, and „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
Gregory Captains, Commi≈ø≈øary Everard, Lievt. Hendly Lievtenant Geff, and one Corporal Brown, formerly committed to the cu≈øtody of the Mar≈øhal-General, and being no Officers in this pre≈øent Army, were on Saturday by his Excellencies
Order di≈øcharged of their impri≈øonments; upon giving ≈øecurity to be „Äà‚óä„Äâ and loyal Subjects to our Soveraign Lord the King, and not to di≈øturb the public peace of his Maje≈øties Kingdomes.

div.head: London.
div.p:
The Artillery Company meeting on Tue≈øday the 26 of June, 1660. at a general Court then held in the Artillery yard, did unanimou≈øly make choice of his Highne≈øs the Duke of York to be their Commander in chief, and made choice of twelve of the Court of A≈ø≈øi≈øtants, to acquaint his Highne≈øs therewith, and de≈øire his acceptance. On Saturday the 30th of June, the Lord Lucas, Sir John Robin≈øon, Lievtenant of the Tower, their Deputy Pre≈øident, with Col. Shepherd, and others of the A≈ø≈øi≈øtants accordingly, went to Whitehall, to attend his Highne≈øs, and being commanded by him to come into his Bed-chamber, the L. Lucas acquainted the Duke that the≈øe Gentlemen of the Artillery Company were come to tender their ≈øervices unto his Highne≈øs, and to acquaint him what they had done in reference to his Election to be their Commander in chief; then Col. Shepherd was de≈øired to declare the mind of the Company, which he did in the≈øe words following:
May it plea≈øe your Highne≈øs,
WE are commanded by the Artillery Company to acquaint you, that at our General Court your Highne≈øs was with one heart and one hand freely cho≈øen to be our Commander in chief; but we dur≈øt not have ≈øo pre≈øumed, had we not known that your Highne≈øs was a Lover of Arms in general, and that in the year 1641. you manifested ≈øo much love to that Company in particular, that you honored us ≈øo far, as to enter your ≈øelf to be a member of it; and is being the ancient cu≈øtome of our Company ≈øtill to have liberty to make choice of one of the members of it to be our Commander, we do humbly pray your Highne≈øs will pardon our boldne≈øs, and be plea≈øed to own us as your own Company, and to accept of our earne≈øt reque≈øt to be our Commander in chief, and we ≈øhall be ready to yeild obedience to your Highne≈øs Commands.
And humbly pray for the encrea≈øe of your Highne≈øs pro≈øperity and happine≈øs.

Upon which motion his Highne≈øs did very lovingly accept of it, and them, and promi≈øed they ≈øhould ≈øtill continue their ancient priviledges and cu≈øtomes, and he would be ready to do what he could for them: Then he asked what number they might be, it was an≈øwered, about four hundred or five hundred, and that they hoped they ≈øhould be above three hundred in Arms on Thur≈øday next to attend him, and if they were commanded, ≈øhould be ready to wait upon him that very day at Whitehall‚ñ™ and when the Company was drawn up, they ≈øhould deliver unto him their leading ≈øtaff, according to cu≈øtome: To which he replyed, He would accept of it, and returned them hearty thanks.

On Friday the 29th, a Committee of Aldermen and Common-Council went to invite the Lords of his Maje≈øties Privy-Council to dinner with them at Guild-hall, July 5. the day appointed by his Maje≈øty, which they were plea≈øed accept of: They likewi≈øe made a particular invitation to the Lord Chancellor, and ≈øeveral other per≈øons of Honor, which they were plea≈øed to accept. His Sacred Maje≈øty in con≈øideration of the eminent ≈øervices and con≈øtant loyalty of Sir John Robin≈øon Knight and Baronet, Alderm ‚Ä¢ n of London, made him Lievtenant of the Tower, which on Friday he took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of.
To morrow Doctor Reynolds is to preach before his Maje≈øty in his Chappel at Whitehall.
London, Printed by John Macock, and Thomas Newcomb, 1660.
